para.p:
This is a norm on

para.p: Integrating by parts,

Math.text: hat@(f) * n = (1 / (2 * pi)) * (integral _ T)@(f * t * e ^ (- i * n * t) * differential-d@(t)) = - (1 / (2 * pi)) * (integral _ T)@((e ^ (- i * n * t) / (- i * n)) * differential-d@(f) * t) = (1 / (2 * pi * i * n)) * (integral _ T)@(e ^ (- i * n * t) * differential-d@(f) * t)

para.p: hence

Math.text: absolute-value@(hat@(f) * n) less= (1 / (2 * pi * absolute-value@(n))) * var * f

para.p:

F * f _ h * n
absent = (1 / (2 * pi)) * (integral _ T)@(f * (t - h) * e ^ (- i * n * t) * differential-d@(t))

absent = (1 / (2 * pi)) * (integral _ T)@(f * t * e ^ (- i * n * (t + h)) * differential-d@(t))
absent = e ^ (- i * n * h) * F * f * n
absent = e ^ (- i * n * h) * F * f * n

para.p: Thus

Math.text: formulae@(F * (f _ h - f) * n = (e ^ (- i * n * h) - 1) * hat@(f) * n, n element-of Z)

para.p:
For

Then

Math.text: (2 * pi) / 3 = 2 ^ m cdot ((2 * pi) / 3) cdot 2 ^ (- m) less= absolute-value@(n * h _ m) less 2 ^ (m + 1) cdot ((2 * pi) / 3) cdot 2 ^ (- m) = (4 * pi) / 3

para.p:
If
> n 0
this implies that

Math.text: pi / 3 less= (n * h _ m) / 2 less (2 * pi) / 3

para.p: and so

Math.text: absolute-value@(e ^ (- i * n * h _ m) - 1) = 2 * sine@((n * h _ m) / 2) >= 2 * sine@(pi / 3) = square-root@(3)

para.p:
and if
< n 0
this implies that

Math.text: - (2 * pi) / 3 less (n * h _ m) / 2 less= - pi / 3

para.p: and so

Math.text: absolute-value@(e ^ (- i * n * h _ m) - 1) >= square-root@(3)

para.p: This gives us

Math.text: (sum _ (2 ^ m less= absolute-value@(n) less 2 ^ (m + 1)))@((absolute-value@(hat@(f) * n)) ^ 2) less= (sum _ (2 ^ m less= absolute-value@(n) less 2 ^ (m + 1)))@(3 * (absolute-value@(hat@(f) * n)) ^ 2)

absent less= (sum _ (n element-of Z))@((absolute-value@(e ^ (- i * n * h _ m) - 1)) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(hat@(f) * n)) ^ 2)
absent less= (sum _ (n element-of Z))@((absolute-value@(e ^ (- i * n * h _ m) - 1)) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(hat@(f) * n)) ^ 2)

para.p: Using () and Parseval’s theorem we have

Math.text: (sum _ (n element-of Z))@((absolute-value@(e ^ (- i * n * h _ m) - 1)) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(hat@(f) * n)) ^ 2) = ((norm@(F * (f _ h _ m - f))) _ (ell ^ 2 * Z)) ^ 2 = ((norm@(f _ h _ m - f)) _ (L ^ 2 * T)) ^ 2

para.p: and thus

The above proof of Wiener’s lemma uses the theory of the commutative Banach algebras. The following is a proof of the theorem that does not use the Gelfand transform. 5 5 footnote 5 Karlheinz Gröchenig, Wiener’s Lemma: Theme and Variations.
